history.content:
I would highly highly recommend CS231n if you are interested in Deep Learning and Computer Vision. You can go to their website for notes and looking at the lectures from youtube. For the lecture, I recommend Winter 2016 version mainly taught by Andrej, who created 231n along with Dr. Feifei Li. Andrej's a great lecturer. With these materials, CS231n is really great for the purpose of self-studying.

Also, self-learning CS231n would give you a HUGE edge if you decide to take CS182 in the future.

CS189's notes (both Prof. Sahai's and Prof. Shewchuk's )are exceptional, and you can watch Prof. Shewchuk's webcast archive. I personally find 189's hard to self-study by oneself because heavy math really needs to be solidated through solving homework and discussion. There are a lot of matrices manipulation as well so if you are not so comfortable with them you probably want to self study some of that (EE127 materials) during the summer.

On the contrary, 231n's math's pretty simple and it's all about concepts. They touch a little bit about optimization as well which could only help you with your 189 for the next semester. Hope this helps!

For the lecture, I recommend Winter 2016 version mainly taught by Andrej, who created 231n along with Dr. Feifei Li. Andrej's a great lecturer. CS189's notes (both Prof. Sahai's and Prof. Shewchuk's )are exceptional, and you can watch Prof. Shewchuk's webcast archive. I personally find 189's hard to self-study by oneself because heavy math really needs to be solidated through solving homework and discussion. There are a lot of matrices manipulation as well so if you are not so comfortable with them you probably want to self study some of that (EE127 materials) during the summer.

On the contrary, 231n's math's pretty simple and it's all about concepts. They touch a little bit about optimization as well which could only help you with your 189 for the next semester. Hope this helps!

children.subject:
I took 189 and 182 concurrently so I think it's very likely you could understand 231n without 189! It's possible there may be some pedagogical benefit to learning 189 material first, maybe someone more knowledgeable could follow up if that's the case.

Chapter 5 of the deep learning book is also a good starting point for basic machine learning material.
Yes, it is doable. Source: self studied 231n without 126 127 189 or 182
Yeah, it's totally doable. Actually, I think it's very beneficial to start with 231n before 189 or 182... it introduces a lot of key ideas in ml and dl without going too deep into the math part.

To follow up on the provided answer, considering the recommendation for CS231n, do you think it's possible for me to take that class and understand its contents without having ML knowledge from 189? That is, would I understand the content in 231n before I've taken 189?

history.content:
Hi everyone,

I wanted to get your advice regarding my plans for the upcoming summer session. As someone who hopes to get involved in ML research next semester, I intend to self-study some of the topics over the summer. However, I am conflicted over which ones to choose to best allocate my time. I will be taking CS 189 next semester but since I hope to get involved in research at the same time, I plan to self-learn the contents of the class over the summer. However, one of my TAs from EECS 126 mentioned that Stanford's CS 231n is also a great course to self-learn before starting research. Hence, I wanted to get your opinion: would you recommend self-studying CS 189 (or the Stanford equivalent CS 229) or CS 231n this summer, considering that I have taken EECS 126 so far only. Unfortunately, I don't think I will be able to do both since I wish to apply the material I will be learning to reimplement a research paper or two that I find interesting in the field (alongside my internship). 

Thanks for your advice!
history.subject: Best course to self-study over the summer?
